schema.headline: The Loop live: Non-prescription vapes to be banned, the search for a Texas gunman enters its third day, and historic TV props up for auction

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US Treasury Secretary says country could default on its debt as early as June 1
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has notified that country's Congress that it could default on its debt as early as June 1, if legislators do not raise or suspend the nation's borrowing authority before then and avert what could potentially become a global financial crisis. In a letter to House and Senate leaders, Yellen urges congressional leaders "to protect the full faith and credit of the United States by acting as soon as possible" to address the $US31.4 trillion ($47.4 trillion) limit on its legal borrowing authority. She says it is impossible to predict with certainty the exact date of when the US will run out of cash. "We have learned from past debt limit impasses that waiting until the last minute to suspend or increase the debt limit can cause serious harm to business and consumer confidence, raise short-term borrowing costs for taxpayers, and negatively impact the credit rating of the United States," Yellen says in her letter. In January, Yellen sent a letter to congressional leaders stating that her department had begun resorting to "extraordinary measures" to avoid a federal government default. The US plans to borrow $1 trillion during the April to June quarter. That's more than projected in January, due to a lower beginning-of-quarter cash balance and projections of lower-than-expected income tax receipts and higher spending.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US police say at least six people have died after dust storm highway crashes
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Police in the US state of Illinois have provided an update on a series of crashes on a local highway during a duststorm, in which around 70-100 vehicles are said to have been hit. Illinois State Police say there are reports of six fatalities, with more than 30 people being transported to hospital for injuries ranging from minor to life-threatening. Those people in hospital range from two years old to 80 years old. "The cause of the crash is due to excessive winds blowing dirt from farm fields across the highway, leading to zero visibility," police say. Around 30 commercial vehicles and 40 to 60 passenger cars are said to be involved in the accidents, including two semi-trailer trucks which caught fire.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Royals release new photo of Princess Charlotte
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prince William and his wife Kate have released a new photo of Princess Charlotte, the day before her eighth birthday. Kensington Palace says Kate took the photo in Windsor last weekend. Charlotte's birthday celebration this year falls just days before King Charles's coronation on Saturday.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer doesn't rule out JobSeeker lift for people over 55
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's the latest on JobSeeker payments from political reporter Jake Evans, after some media outlets reported the payment would be lifted for people over 55 in next week's federal budget. The federal treasurer has refused to confirm whether JobSeeker payments for people over 55 will be lifted for the first time in a decade. Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers said unemployed women over 55 were the most vulnerable cohort in Australian society and the government wanted to introduce specific measures to help them. But he did not rule out the change, saying instead those details would be confirmed next week. The federal government has been under pressure to lift JobSeeker, including from its own backbench. You can keep reading Jake's story below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The Met Gala has begun!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: New York City's Met Gala, which I mentioned, earlier has now kicked off. This year's fashion night-of-nights will be hosted by actor Penélope Cruz, writer and actor Michaela Coel, tennis legend Roger Federer, and singer Dua Lipa. You can follow all of the latest looks and news in my colleague Jess's live blog, below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Minister says new messaging system will make sure Australians get emergency alerts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government is set to roll out a state-of the-art National Messaging System that can send emergency warnings straight to your mobile phone, as part of next week's budget. A further $10.1 million will be put towards improving the communications network used by first responders. Emergency Services Minister Murray Watt tells ABC News Breakfast that people in disaster areas say they hadn't received emergency messages quickly enough in the past. "In some case they're sent to the wrong area. They might have the wrong phone provider and then not receive a message," he says. "So that's what this national messaging system is all about — having one system across the country that can effectively override a mobile phone system and deliver people very targetted, very quick messages." The government says the emergency messages will be easy to tell apart from scam messages. You can read more about the plan for the National Messaging System, below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Fatalities reported after multiple car crashes during US dust storm
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Police in the US state of Illinois say a number of people have been killed and dozens of others have been injured in car crashes along a highway during a dust storm. Illinois State Police says about 40 to 60 passenger cars and several trucks were involved in the crashes. It says about 30 people have been transported to local hospitals with injuries.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ADF reportedly promised $400m for retention bonuses
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Australian Associated Press (AAP) reports that Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel could be up for a $50,000 cash bonus under a federal government push to expand the size of the nation's military. The AAP says the Albanese government will announce it has set aside $400 million for retention bonuses to help reduce the thousands of personnel leaving the armed forces. Permanent ADF members will supposedly be eligible to receive a $50,000 bonus payment near the end of their initial mandatory period of service, if they commit to the military for another three years. Under the scheme, 3,400 personnel will be able to benefit within the first three years. The government has identified ­recruitment and retention of personnel as an immediate priority in response to the defence strategic review.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Coming up: The RBA will make its latest rate decision
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Reserve Bank will weigh up later today whether to resume interest rate rises or continue its recent pause in the official cash rate. The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6 per cent in April after 10 hikes in a row to tame inflation. Consumer prices rose 7 per cent over the year to March, down from 7.8 per cent — but that's still higher than the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target. RBA Governor Philip Lowe has not ruled out further rate hikes. The market is predicting that rates will likely remain on hold when the RBA board makes its announcement at 2:30pm today, but it's not official until it's official.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Twitter is having issues again, and keeps logging people out
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you're noticing anything strange on Twitter this morning — don't worry, you're not alone. Many users (myself included) appear to have been logged out of their accounts on desktop, and can't log back in. Others appear to be able to briefly log in, before being kicked out again. "Twitter keeps logging me out on the web immediately after I sign in. I have tried using my three accounts on different browsers and the result is the same," one user writes on Reddit. Here's how reports of Twitter issues have looked over the past 24 hours, according to Downdetector: Twitter and its CEO Elon Musk are yet to comment on the apparent glitch. The social media platform appears to be working as normal for most people on their mobile devices, luckily. Are you having any issues with Twitter? Let me know in the comments.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US says 20,000 Russians have been killed in Ukraine war since December
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The White House says it now estimates that since December more than 20,000 Russians have been killed as Ukraine rebuffs a heavy assault by Russian forces in eastern Ukraine. White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby says the US estimate is based on newly declassified American intelligence. US General Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in November that Russia had suffered well over 100,000 killed or wounded in the first eight months of the war. The new figures suggest that Russian losses have dramatically accelerated in recent months. The fiercest recent battles in Ukraine have been in the eastern Donetsk region, where Russia is struggling to encircle the city of Bakhmut.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aerosmith announce farewell tour, but no Australian dates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US rockers Aerosmith have announced their farewell tour after 50-plus years together, but Australia has missed out (so far). The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame band have announced the dates for their Peace Out farewell tour, which begins in September and includes 40 shows across the US and Canada. "I think it's about time," guitarist Joe Perry said in an interview with The Associated Press. Perry believes the time to say goodbye is now, especially with every founding band member over the age of 70. Frontman Steven Tyler, 75, is the oldest in the group. "It's kind of a chance to celebrate the 50 years we've been out here," Perry said. "You never know how much longer everybody's going to be healthy to do this. … It's been a while since we've actually done a real tour. We did that run in Vegas, which was great. It was fun, but (we're) kind of anxious to get back on the road."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ban on non-prescription vapes to be announced today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Health Minister Mark Butler is expected to today unveil a plan to stamp out the growing black market for illegal vaping. The Government will allocate $234 million in next week's budget to reduce harm caused by tobacco and vaping products, including to stop the importation of non-prescription vapes. Under the changes, all general practitioners will be able to prescribe flavour-free, plain packaged vapes to patients working to quit smoking. Speaking on Q & A last night, Butler said easy access to vapes had created a new generation of nicotine addicts. "This is now the number one behavioural issue in high schools and it's rapidly becoming a serious behavioural issue in primary schools," he said. "This is a very serious problem we're facing and it has exploded over the last few years. While we were focused on the pandemic, it has utterly exploded and we've got to deal with it now." Butler is expected to further detail the government's plans during a speech at the National Press Club from 12:30pm today .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Search for Texas gunman who killed five neighbours enters third day
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The search for a gunman who fatally shot five neighbours with an AR-style rifle in the US state of Texas has entered a third day, after authorities expanded their search over the weekend while acknowledging they had little sense of the killer's possible whereabouts. On Monday, a heavy presence of police converged in an area where police had reported a possible sighting of the suspect, but later 38-year-old Francisco Oropeza wasn't found despite a search by officers, scent-tracking dogs and aerial police. The false alarm was one of the first times since Friday's shooting in the rural town of Cleveland that authorities had announced a possible sighting of Oropeza. By Sunday evening, authorities said more than 250 officers from multiple jurisdictions had joined the search, and Texas Governor Greg Abbott put up $US50,000 ($75,000) in reward money for tips leading to Oropeza's capture. "I can tell you right now, we have zero leads," said James Smith, the FBI special agent in charge.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australia is searching for: Met Gala 2023
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Celebrities are hitting up New York City's Metropolitan Museum of Art today for the annual charity night and fashion event known as the Met Gala. This year's theme is Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, paying tribute to the German fashion designer who died in 2019 — a theme which has proven to be controversial. Today's red carpet is expected to start live streaming at 8am AEST on Vogue's social media accounts. We will also be live blogging the event in a separate blog, so keep an eye out for that. You can read more about this year's Met Gala at the link below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.

40 shows across the US and Canada
"I think it's about time," guitarist Joe Perry said in an interview with The Associated Press.
Perry believes the time to say goodbye is now, especially with every founding band member over the age of 70.
Frontman Steven Tyler, 75, is the oldest in the group.
"It's kind of a chance to celebrate the 50 years we've been out here," Perry said.

"You never know how much longer everybody's going to be healthy to do this. … It's been a while since we've actually done a real tour. We did that run in Vegas, which was great. It was fun, but (we're) kind of anxious to get back on the road."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Health Minister Mark Butler is expected to today unveil a plan to stamp out the growing black market for illegal vaping. The Government will allocate $234 million in next week's budget to reduce harm caused by tobacco and vaping products, including to stop the importation of non-prescription vapes. Under the changes, all general practitioners will be able to prescribe flavour-free, plain packaged vapes to patients working to quit smoking. Speaking on Q & A last night, Butler said easy access to vapes had created a new generation of nicotine addicts. "This is now the number one behavioural issue in high schools and it's rapidly becoming a serious behavioural issue in primary schools," he said. "This is a very serious problem we're facing and it has exploded over the last few years. While we were focused on the pandemic, it has utterly exploded and we've got to deal with it now." Butler is expected to further detail the government's plans during a speech at the National Press Club from 12:30pm today .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ban on non-prescription vapes to be announced today

props.alt: A close-up of a hand holding an electronic vaping device.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The search for a gunman who fatally shot five neighbours with an AR-style rifle in the US state of Texas has entered a third day, after authorities expanded their search over the weekend while acknowledging they had little sense of the killer's possible whereabouts. On Monday, a heavy presence of police converged in an area where police had reported a possible sighting of the suspect, but later 38-year-old Francisco Oropeza wasn't found despite a search by officers, scent-tracking dogs and aerial police. The false alarm was one of the first times since Friday's shooting in the rural town of Cleveland that authorities had announced a possible sighting of Oropeza. By Sunday evening, authorities said more than 250 officers from multiple jurisdictions had joined the search, and Texas Governor Greg Abbott put up $US50,000 ($75,000) in reward money for tips leading to Oropeza's capture. "I can tell you right now, we have zero leads," said James Smith, the FBI special agent in charge.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Search for Texas gunman who killed five neighbours enters third day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Celebrities are hitting up New York City's Metropolitan Museum of Art today for the annual charity night and fashion event known as the Met Gala. This year's theme is Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, paying tribute to the German fashion designer who died in 2019 — a theme which has proven to be controversial. Today's red carpet is expected to start live streaming at 8am AEST on Vogue's social media accounts. We will also be live blogging the event in a separate blog, so keep an eye out for that. You can read more about this year's Met Gala at the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police in the US state of Illinois have provided an update on a series of crashes on a local highway during a duststorm, in which around 70-100 vehicles are said to have been hit. Illinois State Police say there are reports of six fatalities, with more than 30 people being transported to hospital for injuries ranging from minor to life-threatening. Those people in hospital range from two years old to 80 years old. "The cause of the crash is due to excessive winds blowing dirt from farm fields across the highway, leading to zero visibility," police say. Around 30 commercial vehicles and 40 to 60 passenger cars are said to be involved in the accidents, including two semi-trailer trucks which caught fire.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US police say at least six people have died after dust storm highway crashes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank will weigh up later today whether to resume interest rate rises or continue its recent pause in the official cash rate. The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6 per cent in April after 10 hikes in a row to tame inflation. Consumer prices rose 7 per cent over the year to March, down from 7.8 per cent — but that's still higher than the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target. RBA Governor Philip Lowe has not ruled out further rate hikes. The market is predicting that rates will likely remain on hold when the RBA board makes its announcement at 2:30pm today, but it's not official until it's official.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up: The RBA will make its latest rate decision

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I actually love this a lot, maybe because I'm digging the hair so much.

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I have been wishing and waiting for a stunning full length photo of this look and now I can finally share it. Another favourite of mine from tonight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Stop everything! Robert Pattinson is here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I am OBSESSED with this man. Borderline unhinged right now seeing him at the Met Gala. And his girlfriend Suki Waterhouse, singer and star of Daisy Jones and the Six, looks absolutely stunning.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Hugh Jackman and Deborra-Lee Furness have arrived at the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And they're continuing the trend away from white. It's a good call, black makes it way harder to tell when you've spilled tomato sauce on your outfit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Margot Robbie was the last Chanel ambassador Karl Lagerfeld picked
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Another Aussie alert! Margot Robbie is here and she's looking gorgeous. I will get us pics ASAP! She's wearing the same dress worn by Cindy Crawford in 1993. "They remade it for me and it's a Karl design so I feel really great in it actually," she said on the red carpet. "Obviously the Met is also an exciting night but I had the great privilege of getting to know Karl to an extent, I was the last Chanel ambassador that he picked, so it's an honour, I'm thrilled they're honouring him tonight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's why Nicole Kidman's dress might look familiar
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's the same dress she wore in her 2004 Chanel No. 5 commercial she did with Australian director Baz Luhrmann. "I think my deep, deep love of Karl came from this time together," Nicole said on the Met Gala red carpet. "So to be able to honour him and wear this dress for Chanel, I suppose the way these couture gowns last. If you take care of them and love them, they are timeless."

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You gotta keep the drama under wraps!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aussie alert! Our Nicole has arrived
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Nicole Kidman and Keith Urban are walking the steps of the Megt Gala. I'm working hard to get you a full length shot of Nicole's dress.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Penelope Cruz
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Another co-chair! I'm seeing a lot of white gowns on the carpet this year.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Emma Chamberlain in blue
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I am SUCH a fan of Emma Chamberlain and I'm loving this blue fit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How much is a Met Gala ticket?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's not really about how much a ticket costs, because even celebrities can't just buy a ticket. The Met Gala is so exclusive that you have to be invited. Generally companies buy tables. A fashion label would then host its desired celebrities. This year, the cost has gone up, as it does every few years because even the Met isn't immune to inflation: It's now $50,000 for an individual ticket, and tables start at $300,000 .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dua Lipa has arrived!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: She's the first Met Gala co-chair I've spotted tonight. Fans have already clocked she's wearing Chanel Fall/Winter 1992 couture.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Who are this year's Met Gala co-chairs and what do they actually do?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: This year's five hosts are drawn from television, film, sports and music, including: Emmy-winning writer, actor and producer Michaela Coel Oscar-winning actor Penélope Cruz, who has worked with Chanel for more than 20 years recently retired tennis superstar Roger Federer Grammy-winner Dua Lipa Finally, there is Vogue's Anna Wintour (who needs no introduction) running the whole thing as usual. So what do co-chairs actually do ? It's a mix of helping put together the exclusive guest list, working with top chefs to create a specific menu (often aligned with the annual theme) and creating an atmosphere inside the event by selecting specific decor. Plus, there's the traditional hosting element, with co-chairs often taking the stage to perform during the dinner portion of the evening. Phones are strictly off limits, so sadly we never get to see any performances or interior design choices.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Vogue editor Anna Wintour has arrived
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And she's walking the steps of the Met with actor Bill Nighy.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: No, Kim Kardashian hasn't been banned from the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Since the Met is invite-only, it's only when guests walk the red carpet that we know who made the cut. This year, there will be roughly 400 guests — similar to recent years but still lower than pre-pandemic highs of 500-600. As always, Anna Wintour and her team still get to approve every guest. Back in March, gossip tabloid Page Six reported that in Wintour's bid to narrow the guest list, the entire Kardashian clan had been culled. But it looks like the rumours were false, as Kim Kardashian posted these photos with Karl Lagerfeld's cat, Choupette, after spending some time at his office to "get inspiration" ahead of the event. Personally, I predict we'll spot Kendall Jenner (she was featured on Vogue's May cover which paid tribute to Lagerfeld) and I hope and pray Kylie Jenner will debut her relationship with Timothée Chalamet because that would be INTERESTING.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How to watch the Met Gala red carpet arrivals
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You can watch the whole shebang on the Vogue live stream below, which is due to go live in about 30 minutes.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why the Met's decision to honour Karl Lagerfeld is controversial
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: This year's theme centers on the late designer Karl Lagerfeld, who made an indelible mark on luxury fashion in his long career at Chanel, Fendi and elsewhere. He was also a self-proclaimed "big mouth," publicly sounding off with fatphobia. He spoke against gay men who want to adopt children, migrants, sexual assault survivors, the #MeToo movement and "ugly" people, without apology. "He offended people right and left, making as much of an art out of the cutting aside as the perfectly cut double-face gown," New York Times fashion critic Vanessa Friedman wrote soon after Lagerfeld's death. "He judged," Friedman wrote, "and knew he would be judged himself, but he didn't care. Rather, he embraced it." The choice of Lagerfeld for fashion's biggest night is not without critics. At the time of the announcement, actor and activist Jameela Jamil acknowledge his fashion genius but denounce his "distinctly hateful" remarks, often toward women. "Why is THIS who we celebrate when there are so many AMAZING designers out there who aren't bigoted white men?" Jamil wrote. According to the Met, Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, will look at "the designer's stylistic vocabulary as expressed in aesthetic themes that appear time and again in his fashions from the 1950s to his final collection in 2019." Lagerfeld died in 2019 at the age of 85.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to the 2023 Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The time has come! Fashion's biggest night is HERE. I'm Jessica Riga and I am so stoked to be bringing you all the glitz, glamour and celebrity moments from the red carpet of the Met Gala. It's also the first time in two years the Met Gala has returned to its traditional date — the first Monday in May (well, Tuesday for us.) I want to hear what you think of what everyone is wearing, so sound off in the comments, smash those reactions and let's get this fashion extravaganza underway!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not really about how much a ticket costs, because even celebrities can't just buy a ticket. The Met Gala is so exclusive that you have to be invited. Generally companies buy tables. A fashion label would then host its desired celebrities. This year, the cost has gone up, as it does every few years because even the Met isn't immune to inflation: It's now $50,000 for an individual ticket, and tables start at $300,000 .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This year's five hosts are drawn from television, film, sports and music, including: Emmy-winning writer, actor and producer Michaela Coel Oscar-winning actor Penélope Cruz, who has worked with Chanel for more than 20 years recently retired tennis superstar Roger Federer Grammy-winner Dua Lipa Finally, there is Vogue's Anna Wintour (who needs no introduction) running the whole thing as usual. So what do co-chairs actually do ? It's a mix of helping put together the exclusive guest list, working with top chefs to create a specific menu (often aligned with the annual theme) and creating an atmosphere inside the event by selecting specific decor. Plus, there's the traditional hosting element, with co-chairs often taking the stage to perform during the dinner portion of the evening. Phones are strictly off limits, so sadly we never get to see any performances or interior design choices.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Since the Met is invite-only, it's only when guests walk the red carpet that we know who made the cut. This year, there will be roughly 400 guests — similar to recent years but still lower than pre-pandemic highs of 500-600. As always, Anna Wintour and her team still get to approve every guest. Back in March, gossip tabloid Page Six reported that in Wintour's bid to narrow the guest list, the entire Kardashian clan had been culled. But it looks like the rumours were false, as Kim Kardashian posted these photos with Karl Lagerfeld's cat, Choupette, after spending some time at his office to "get inspiration" ahead of the event. Personally, I predict we'll spot Kendall Jenner (she was featured on Vogue's May cover which paid tribute to Lagerfeld) and I hope and pray Kylie Jenner will debut her relationship with Timothée Chalamet because that would be INTERESTING.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This year's theme centers on the late designer Karl Lagerfeld, who made an indelible mark on luxury fashion in his long career at Chanel, Fendi and elsewhere. He was also a self-proclaimed "big mouth," publicly sounding off with fatphobia. He spoke against gay men who want to adopt children, migrants, sexual assault survivors, the #MeToo movement and "ugly" people, without apology. "He offended people right and left, making as much of an art out of the cutting aside as the perfectly cut double-face gown," New York Times fashion critic Vanessa Friedman wrote soon after Lagerfeld's death. "He judged," Friedman wrote, "and knew he would be judged himself, but he didn't care. Rather, he embraced it." The choice of Lagerfeld for fashion's biggest night is not without critics. At the time of the announcement, actor and activist Jameela Jamil acknowledge his fashion genius but denounce his "distinctly hateful" remarks, often toward women. "Why is THIS who we celebrate when there are so many AMAZING designers out there who aren't bigoted white men?" Jamil wrote. According to the Met, Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, will look at "the designer's stylistic vocabulary as expressed in aesthetic themes that appear time and again in his fashions from the 1950s to his final collection in 2019." Lagerfeld died in 2019 at the age of 85.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why the Met's decision to honour Karl Lagerfeld is controversial

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The time has come! Fashion's biggest night is HERE. I'm Jessica Riga and I am so stoked to be bringing you all the glitz, glamour and celebrity moments from the red carpet of the Met Gala. It's also the first time in two years the Met Gala has returned to its traditional date — the first Monday in May (well, Tuesday for us.) I want to hear what you think of what everyone is wearing, so sound off in the comments, smash those reactions and let's get this fashion extravaganza underway!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Housing affordability worsens as property prices rise for second straight month
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: House prices have risen for the second month in a row, with analysts suggesting the market may have bottomed. Rents are also rising, which is putting extra pressure on the federal government to do something about the affordability crisis. It says it's not considering scrapping tax concessions, like negative gearing for investors, but will offer tax breaks to developers in next week's budget to build more rental properties. You can watch the full story from my colleague, business reporter Nassim Khadem below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Incoming Qantas CEO says it's an 'honour' to lead national carrier
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'It's a logical time for me to step down', Joyce says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Outgoing Qantas boss Alan Joyce was asked to stay on as the airline's CEO as it recovered from the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Mr Joyce says now is the right time to step aside. "Now that we’re on the other side of that crisis it’s a logical time for me to step down," he said. "There’s still a  lot I want to deliver in the next six months and at the top of that list is ensuring a smooth handover to  Vanessa, who I’m sure will excel in the role." Qantas chair Richard Goyder paid tribute to Mr Joyce for his years at the helm of the national carrier. “Much of the credit for the bright future in front of Qantas goes to Alan," Mr Goyder said. "He’s faced more than his fair share  of challenges as CEO and he’s managed them exceptionally well – from the GFC, to record oil prices, to  intense competitive pressures and the COVID crisis. "The company was restructured to deal with a number of external shocks and Alan led it to a several record  profits. "Alan has done a superb job of leading a team that is absolutely committed to the national carrier’s long-term success and it’s from that team that his successor has been chosen."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BREAKING: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce to step down in November, replaced by CFO Vanessa Hudson
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could the government see a budget surplus by the end of the year?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: House prices haven't just stabilised — they've turned the corner
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. You can read more of this analysis by business editor Ian Verrender below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below 👇

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Incoming Qantas CEO says it's an 'honour' to lead national carrier

children.content: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history.

"It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said.
"My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Qantas boss Alan Joyce was asked to stay on as the airline's CEO as it recovered from the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Mr Joyce says now is the right time to step aside. "Now that we’re on the other side of that crisis it’s a logical time for me to step down," he said. "There’s still a  lot I want to deliver in the next six months and at the top of that list is ensuring a smooth handover to  Vanessa, who I’m sure will excel in the role." Qantas chair Richard Goyder paid tribute to Mr Joyce for his years at the helm of the national carrier. “Much of the credit for the bright future in front of Qantas goes to Alan," Mr Goyder said. "He’s faced more than his fair share  of challenges as CEO and he’s managed them exceptionally well – from the GFC, to record oil prices, to  intense competitive pressures and the COVID crisis. "The company was restructured to deal with a number of external shocks and Alan led it to a several record  profits. "Alan has done a superb job of leading a team that is absolutely committed to the national carrier’s long-term success and it’s from that team that his successor has been chosen."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It's a logical time for me to step down', Joyce says
